posts.author: glad
posts.post_text: February 17, 2013 at 11:14 PM#2you may select fixtures by name (with wildcard *)assuming than you have not renamed your fixtures your washes will be labeledVL2500Wa 1VL2500Wa 2etcand your spotsVL2500Sp 1VL2500Sp 2etcso to select the washes you could doFixture "VL2500Wa*and for spotsFixture "VL2500Sp*

posts.author: Duplicate dherderich
posts.post_text: March 29, 2013 at 6:35 PM#4There exists the FixtureType keyword for the commandline.But it can only handle the IDs of the Fixturetypes.With the command List FixtureType you can get a list of the IDs and the associated FixtureTypes in your Showfile.Maybe you can work with it?

posts.author: Duplicate MarkvanderMeulen
posts.post_text: March 31, 2013 at 4:20 PM#5I used the method explained bij Glad, it works also if you use the just the name, for example: if you use CP Sharpy's, you can use the keywords; Fixture Sharpy*, the console will select all the patched Sharpy's, whenever you are using te vector lamp on/of or standard lamp on/off fixture filesThis works also for VL2500 when using the command: Fixture VL2500*, but then it will also select the VL2500 WashesSo what i do now is, i make the correct patch, use a few macro's to create gobo, shutter, color and effectwheel presets and after that i change the names of the fixtures when nessesary, with this method i have my presets ready in a mather of seconds and start being creativeSo it is not exactly what i wanted to do, but for now it works pretty wellThanks for your input!!

posts.author: glad
posts.post_text: April 1, 2013 at 1:35 AM#6a possible workaround to select fixtures of a specific fixturetype could be to go via a sheet and its masking featuree.g. a Fixturesheet is first window of second screenAssign Fixturetype 4 At Screen 2.1-> Sheet gets masked showing only fixtures of type 4Selfix Screen 2.1-> Select fixtures displayed by the masked sheet.
